definitions.definition: not high or tall; not far above the ground

examples.text: a low wall/building/table
The fence is too low.
a low range of hills
low clouds
flying at low altitude
The sun was low in the sky.

definitions.definition: at or near the bottom of something

examples.text: low back pain
the lower slopes of the mountain
temperatures in the low 20s *(= no higher than 21–23°)*

definitions.definition: not high at the neck

examples.text: a dress with a low neckline
The neckline was much lower than she was used to.
The dress had a V-neck and a very low back.
tight sweaters and low-neck shirts

definitions.definition: below the usual or average amount, level or value

examples.text: a **low level** of unemployment
**lower prices/costs**
the **lowest rates** of interest for 40 years
the **lowest temperature **ever recorded
**low-income** families
a **low-cost** airline
There is a **low risk **of failure.
Incomes are **significantly lower** than in other parts of the country.
areas with **relatively low** unemployment
This yogurt is very low in fat.
The failure rate is extremely low.
The government wants to keep taxes low.
historically low marriage statistics
Their ready meals are low in sugar and salt.

definitions.definition: below the usual water level

examples.text: The reservoir was low after the long drought.

definitions.definition: having a reduced amount or not enough of something

examples.text: Our supplies are **running low** *(= we only have a little left)*.
Our stocks of food were getting low.
A warning light flashes when the battery is low.
They were low on fuel.

definitions.definition: below the usual or expected standard

examples.text: Students with the lowest scores retook the test.
low marks/grades
a low standard of living
Much of the work was of a very low standard.
These measures will lead to a lower quality of life for many older people.

definitions.definition: below other people or things in importance or status

examples.text: lower forms of life *(= creatures with a very simple structure)*
jobs with low status
Training was given a very low priority.

definitions.definition: not very good

examples.text: She has a very low opinion of her own abilities.

definitions.definition: not high; not loud

examples.text: The cello is lower than the violin.
They were speaking in low voices.
Keep your voice low.

definitions.definition: weak or depressed; with very little energy

examples.text: I'm feeling really low.
They were in low spirits.
I think he got a bit low when he had the flu.

definitions.definition: not honest

examples.text: He mixes with some pretty low types.

definitions.definition: not bright

examples.text: The lights were low and romance was in the air.

definitions.definition: if a vehicle is in low gear, it travels at a slower speed in relation to the speed of the engine
produced with the tongue in the lowest possible position
in a poor state; worse than usual

examples.text: Morale among teachers is at a low ebb.

definitions.definition: to lose your wealth or your high position in society
the amount of attention somebody/something has from the public

examples.text: This issue has had a high profile in recent months.
I advised her to **keep a low profile** for the next few days *(= not to attract attention)*.
The story was given a low profile in today's papers.

definitions.definition: if somebody is laid low by/with an injury or illness, they feel very weak and are unable to do much
people who are not respected at all because they are not honest, moral or important at all

wordOrigin: adjective Middle English: from Old Norse lágr, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch laag, also to lie.
